Convert rational numbers between different bases and different representations: 

https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.tessoft.qonvert

or

https://f-droid.org/packages/org.tessoft.qonvert/

<style>
    body {padding-top: 1.5em; padding-bottom: 2em}
    h1, h2, h3, h4 {font-family: serif}
    h1 {font-size: 140%}
    h2 {font-size: 125%; border-radius: 0.2em; background: rgb(224, 224, 224)}
    h3 {font-size: 115%}
    h1 small {color: silver}
    ul {padding-left: 1.5em}
    a {color: rgb(224, 83, 0)} /* orange_light */
    code {font-family: inherit; border: 1px solid rgb(224, 224, 224); border-bottom-color: rgb(224, 83, 0); border-radius: 2px}
    .roman-frame {border: 1px solid black; border-bottom: none}
</style>

<style>
    body {color: white; background: rgb(18, 18, 18)}
    h2 {background: rgb(64, 64, 64)}
    code {border-color: rgb(64, 64, 64); border-bottom-color: rgb(168, 62, 0)} /* orange_dark */
    .roman-frame {border-color: white}
</style>

Overview

This app lets you convert numbers from the set â„š of rational numbers between different bases (including nonstandard numeral systems) and between different representations such as positional notation and fractions (including improper, mixed, continued and Egyptian ones). The numbers can have basically arbitrary size and precision.

Long-tap a key on the keyboard to access the second character. You can vanish the keyboard by tapping â—€ on the navigation bar or by swiping down; tap the input line for it to re-emerge.

Short-tap a result to copy it to the input line, and long-tap to copy it to the clipboard.

Choosing input and output systems

Choose an input base via the slider or the shortcut buttons in the lower part of the screen, and an output base via the corresponding controls in the upper part. You can choose the displayed shortcut buttons, including ones to switch to negative bases, in the settings under â€œShow base buttonsâ€. Long-tapping a button or moving a slider all the way to the right brings up a dialog for choosing a base between Â±2 and Â±280 or Ï† (the golden ratio).

The coloured buttons on the right let you switch between various kinds of numeral systems (standard, balanced, bijective, Greek, and Roman), on which more below. Not every option can be combined with every base; for invalid combinations, the buttons are greyed and the app uses the standard numeral system.

You can also prefix a number with one of five tokens (@ %23 $ % &) to set its base and numeral system on the fly. The meaning of these tokens can be changed in the settings; by default, they represent bases 2, 8, 10, 12 and 16 in the standard system, respectively.

Standard positional notation

If you choose to convert from standard DECimal (base 10) to standard HEXadecimal (base 16), an input of (say) 345 is interpreted as 3Ã—102+4Ã—101+5Ã—100 and converted to 1Ã—162+5Ã—161+9Ã—160, which is displayed as 159.

Digits from 0 to 9 work as expected. Those with values higher than 9 are represented by letters and other characters, from A = 10 to Z = 35, Ã = 36, Ğ§ = 37, Ê” = 38, Ê– = 39, etc. (Swipe left to see the Cheat sheet for further digits and how to type them.)

The digits are case insensitive; and spaces are ignored.

Non-integers

Digits after a radix point . are of course interpreted as the fractional part of the number: 1.A6 in DOZenal (base 12) is 1Ã—120+10Ã—12âˆ’1+6Ã—12âˆ’2 = 1.875 decimal. If there is a repeating part, mark its start with a dot above Ë™ (or with a colon : if you are using the Android keyboard instead of Qonvertâ€™s): For example, 0.1Ë™486 means 0.1486486486â€¦, and 21Ë™3.4 means 213.43434â€¦.

The result of your conversion has always either a finite number of digits after the radix point or a repeating part. Sometimes, though, the representation can be very long. To keep the app from freezing, the search for an exact representation stops after 300 digits by default. You can change this value in the settings.

If your screen is too small to show all the output formats (positional, fraction, mixed, continued and Egyptian fractions), you can swipe the output area up and down.

Fractions

Type a numerator and a denominator separated with a slash /, as in 6/8 or 1.5/2. Fractions are reduced or expanded as necessary, so both of these inputs will result in 3/4.

For mixed fractions, separate integer and fractional part with an underscore _: for example 1_9/8, or something more complicated such as 1.Ë™3 _ 1/3. Fractions with an absolute value over 1 will be shown both as improper (17/8 or 5/3 in our examples) and as mixed fractions (2_1/8 or 1_2/3).

Base tokens apply to the individual parts of fractions, so you can type $10_@10/&13 or %251B/14 (where 14 is interpreted according to the currently set base and numeral system). The same is true of the other types of compound numbers described below.

Continued fractions

Continued fractions start with an integer part, followed by a semicolon ; and a comma-separated list of denominators. Square brackets are used for output but are optional for input.

2;3,4, for example, means 2 + 1/(3 + 1/4), which evaluates to 2.Ë™307692, 30/13, and 2_4/13.

Input of non-integer numbers, including fractions, is okay: 1.5; 2/3, 1_1/5 is simplified to [2; 6], which only contains integers. All continued fractions are displayed with positive denominators, so -3;-1,-1,-18 becomes [âˆ’4; 2, 18].

Egyptian fractions

Egyptian fractions are sums of unit fractions. Input works as with continued fractions, only with curly braces: {2;3,4 is interpreted as 2 + 1/3 + 1/4, evaluating to 2.58Ë™3, 31/12, 2_7/12, and [2; 1, 1, 2, 2].

For every rational number there are infinitely many Egyptian fraction representations. In the settings you can choose between various calculation methods for the main screen. The results of the other methods show up when you tap â›¶ in the title bar â€“ they are identical for some numbers, while for others they differ dramatically.

Calculation of an Egyptian fraction may be cut off if it gets too long; the limit depends on the â€œMaximum digits in fractional partâ€ in the settings.

Degrees, minutes and seconds

For example, the input 1Â° 23\' 45\" equals 1+23/60+45/3600 = 67/48 = 1.3958Ë™3 in standard decimal. The three parts of this format have to be in that order, but need not all be present; and they can be non-integers as well: thus, 1Â° 45.6\" and 1/2\' (half a minute) are valid inputs.

The DMS switch at the top right determines whether numbers are output in normal positional notation or as degrees, minutes and seconds.

Negative numbers

You can type negative numbers either in ordinary notation with a leading minus -, or in complement notation with two leading points ..: these points basically mean â€œthe highest digit in this base repeated all the way to the leftâ€. Complement notation works with positive bases in the standard system. It is known from computing, where âˆ’1 is represented as hexadecimal FFFFFFFF, âˆ’2 as FFFFFFFE, and so on (with as many Fâ€™s as there is space). So, typing ..FFD or simply ..D in hexadecimal, or ..997 or simply ..7 in decimal, all mean âˆ’3.

Output of negative numbers is either in ordinary or complement notation, depending on the complement switch at the top right.

Non-standard numeral systems

Balanced

Balanced numeral systems (the best-known being balanced ternary, i.e. base 3) have digits with negative values, notably Z = âˆ’1, Y = âˆ’2, down to J = âˆ’17 and below. (Swipe left to see the Cheat sheet for further digits as defined for balanced systems.) They work with odd bases up to 259. Thus, in balanced ternary, 10Z means 1Ã—32+0Ã—31âˆ’1Ã—30 = 8. Negative numbers donâ€™t need a minus sign in this notation: Z01 means âˆ’1Ã—32+0Ã—31+1Ã—30 = âˆ’8

Bijective

In a bijective system of a base b, the digits go from 1 to b instead of 0 to bâˆ’1. There are two variants: â€œbijective 1â€ uses the digits 1 to 9 and from A upwards as in standard notation and works up to base 279; â€œbijective Aâ€ uses A = 1, B = 2, â€¦ Z = 26, Ã = 27, etc., and only works up to base 270. So, the first natural numbers in decimal bijective 1 are 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, A (=10), 11, 12, â€¦, 19, 1A, 21, â€¦, and the first natural numbers in hexavigesimal (base 26) bijective A are A, B, C, D, â€¦, X, Y, Z, AA, AB, AC, â€¦. Zero is technically an empty string; it is denoted with â€œ/â€.

Numbers with a radix point donâ€™t work well with bijective systems, so non-integers are only displayed as fractions.

Greek numerals

Greek (Milesian) numerals are always base 10. The Greek letters Î‘ Î’ Î“ Î” Î• Ïš Î– Î— Î˜ have values 1 to 9, Î™ Îš Î› Îœ Î Î ÎŸ Î  Ï are 10 to 90, Î¡ Î£ Î¤ Î¥ Î¦ Î§ Î¨ Î© Ï  are 100 to 900, and ÍµÎ‘ ÍµÎ’ ÍµÎ“ etc. are 1000 to 9000. They are normally ordered from largest to smallest: 1231 is ÍµÎ‘Î£Î›Î‘. In the output section they are followed by a keraia (Í´) to better distinguish them from Roman numerals (see below), but the keraia is optional for input.

Myriads (10 000s) are marked with a dot, following Diophantus: Î˜.Î¦Î› means 9 myriads 530 = 90530. Repeated dots are used for still larger numbers (Î  . . Í´ for 80 0000 0000), following nobody at all.

â—‹ means zero. Non-integers are only displayed as fractions.

When Greek input is set, Arabic (i.e. standard decimal) input is also accepted so you need less switching between input systems. Furthermore, Greek numerals are always accepted regardless of input system as they â€“ consisting of Greek letters â€“ canâ€™t be confused with anything else.

When an output system other than Greek is selected, positive integers are also displayed as Greek numerals in the second output line.

Roman numerals

Roman numerals are also base 10. They can contain the letters I V X L C D M. Symbols for larger values are â† = 5000, â†‚ = 10 000, â†‡ = 50 000, and â†ˆ = 100 000. (If you are using the Android keyboard instead of Qonvertâ€™s, you can compose them as I)) ((I)) I))) (((I))).)

One traditional way for expressing still larger numbers is to enclose them in a frame to multiply with 100 000, or in nested frames for even higher powers. Qonvert uses pipes | for this purpose: |VI|((I))MM = VIâ†‚MM = 6 12000. You can omit the leading pipes, and replace pipes with exclamation marks: ||V|M|II = V!M!II = 5 01000 00002. (The Romans certainly wouldnâ€™t have recognised this notation, but there doesnâ€™t seem to be any valid way of expressing huge numbers in Roman.)

The integer part may be followed by S (semis) for a half and one or more dots for a twelfth each. N for nulla or nihil means zero.

When Roman input is set, Arabic (standard decimal) input is also accepted; and when an output system other than Roman is selected, positive integers are also displayed as Roman numerals in the third output line.

Special bases

Phinary

Phinary, base Ï† = (1+âˆš5Ì„)/2, is available in the standard and balanced numeral systems, the difference being that the digit Z = âˆ’1 can be used in the latter. On the sliders, phinary is located on the leftmost tick.

Although the golden ratio Ï† is irrational, integers expressed in base Ï† always have finite representations (albeit typically with digits after the radix point), and non-integer rational numbers have repeating representations. However, the reverse is not true: if you type an arbitrary sequence of digits, you will likely get an error message along the lines of â€œ101áµ© (5/2+âˆš5/2) isnâ€™t rationalâ€.

The output will only contain the digits 0 and 1 (Z for negative numbers in balanced), and never two or more 1â€™s (or Zâ€™s) in a row. The parts of fractions, including continued and Egyptian ones, arenâ€™t necessarily integers, but they are always numbers without a radix point. (Letâ€™s coin a cheesy term: they are always phintegers.) Egyptian fractions can be calculated with the greedy or the phinary remainder method. Phinary output currently does not support fractions in DMS format.

Negative bases

Negative bases work together with all standard and non-standard systems â€“ including all non-integer notations â€“ except for Greek and Roman numerals and for base Ï†. Since odd powers of negative numbers are negative, and even powers are positive, 345 in standard nega-decimal is interpreted as 3Ã—102âˆ’4Ã—101+5Ã—100, which equals 265, and 3450 as âˆ’3Ã—103+4Ã—102âˆ’5Ã—101, which equals âˆ’2650: thus, we donâ€™t need a minus sign in negative bases.

Note that â€œbijectiveâ€ systems with negative bases arenâ€™t actually bijective: for example, in nega-decimal, you can always add or remove a leading 1A without changing a numberâ€™s value.

Complex bases

Although Qonvert canâ€™t handle complex bases, there are some hacks:

  • A real number in base 2i is just this number in base âˆ’4 with zeroes inserted at every other place: âˆ’13.5â‚â‚€ = 1303.2â‚‹â‚„ = 1030003.02â‚‚áµ¢.
  • This also works for higher imaginary bases, always using the negative base that is their square: base âˆ’9 for base 3i etc.
  • You can work out base iâˆ’1 representations by converting to base âˆ’4 and then doing the following digit substitutions:
    0 â†’ 0000, 1 â†’ 0001, 2 â†’ 1100, 3 â†’ 1101

Unicode characters

Inputs that are integers from hexadecimal 20 to 10FFFF (decimal 32 to 1114111) are not only converted to their representation in the output base and to Greek and Roman numerals, but also to the corresponding Unicode character. (If the output area is too cluttered for your taste, you can hide any or all of these in the settings.)

Conversely, type double quotes \" followed by any character to find its Unicode encoding. This only works for single characters, not composed ones such as certain letter-diacritic combinations, people with skin tones, or flags.

The Web has excellent sources to find Unicode characters by name; but if you want to know the Unicode representation of the tortoise in balanced undecimal, Qonvert is your only source. (The answer is 1YX 215.)

And if anybody asks â€œwhyâ€, the answer is â€œbecauseâ€.

Gestures

  • Output area: short-tap copies to input line and switches input and output bases, long-tap copies to clipboard.
  • Base buttons: left/right swipe decreases/increases base by 1, long-tap brings up dialog for choosing a base.
  • â€œin: baseâ€ and â€œout: baseâ€: tap displays digit range for currently selected base and number system.
  • Number system buttons: long-tap toggles between standard and balanced.
  • Base sliders: sliding all the way to the right brings up dialog for choosing a base.
  • Clear button (ğŸ—‘): long-tap sets input and output to standard decimal.
  • Qonvert keyboard: long-tap accesses the second character on a key; â—€ or swiping down vanishes it, and tapping the input line lets it re-emerge.
  • List entries in history etc.: short-tap copies to input line, long-tap toggles selection. In selection mode, long-tap selects a range.

Input syntax

Digits

  • 0â€¦9
  • Aâ€¦Z and Ã Ğ§ Ê” Ê– : 10â€¦39; bijective A: 1â€¦30
  • Ä„â€¦áº’ and ê¦ Ò¶ ? Â¿ : 40â€¦69; bij.A: 31â€¦60
  • Èºâ€¦Æµ and ê¤ Ò¸ Ê¡ Æ¾ : 70â€¦99; bij.A: 61â€¦90
  • â’¶â€¦â“ and ãŠ„ ãŠƒ ãŠˆ ãŠ† : 100â€¦129; bij.A: 91â€¦120
  • â’œâ€¦â’µ and ãˆ¤ ãˆ£ ãˆ¨ ãˆ¦ : 130â€¦159; bij.A: 121â€¦150
  • å‚â€¦ä¹™ and äº” å›› ä¹ ä¸ƒ : 160â€¦189; bij.A: 151â€¦180
  • ê‹¬â€¦ê´ and êƒ© ê³ êƒ€ ê§ : 190â€¦219; bij.A: 181â€¦210
  • á—©â€¦á” and á˜¶ á–» á•ˆ á˜ª : 220â€¦249; bij.A: 211â€¦240
  • áš£â€¦á›‹ and áš¦ áš´ áš¯ áš¬ : 250â€¦279; bij.A: 241â€¦270

The latter turn up in a pop-up when you tap one of the letters Aâ€“Ê–, depending on the current input system.

If â€œSettings > Keyboard > Space key composes digitâ€ is switched on, you can also type a digitâ€™s decimal value and then tap Space â£. (On some Android keyboards, you may need two spaces.)

In balanced number systems

  • áš±â€¦á›‹ and áš¦ áš´ áš¯ áš¬ : âˆ’129â€¦âˆ’117
  • ê‹¬â€¦ê´ and êƒ© ê³ êƒ€ ê§ : âˆ’116â€¦âˆ’87
  • â’œâ€¦â’µ and ãˆ¤ ãˆ£ ãˆ¨ ãˆ¦ : âˆ’86â€¦âˆ’57
  • Èºâ€¦Æµ and ê¤ Ò¸ Ê¡ Æ¾ : âˆ’56â€¦âˆ’27
  • Ä„â€¦Ä® : âˆ’26â€¦âˆ’18
  • Jâ€¦Z : âˆ’17â€¦âˆ’1
  • 0â€¦9
  • Aâ€¦I : 10â€¦18
  • ê²â€¦áº’ and ê¦ Ò¶ ? Â¿ : 19â€¦39
  • â’¶â€¦â“ and ãŠ„ ãŠƒ ãŠˆ ãŠ† : 40â€¦69
  • å‚â€¦ä¹™ and äº” å›› ä¹ ä¸ƒ : 70â€¦99
  • á—©â€¦á” and á˜¶ á–» á•ˆ á˜ª : 100â€¦129

Negative numbers

  • - : minus sign
  • .. : complement notation

Non-integers

  • . : radix point
  • Ë™ or : : start of repeating part
  • / : fraction slash
  • _ : separates integer and fraction in a mixed fraction (e.g. 2_1/8)
  • Â° \' \" : degrees, minutes and seconds
  • [ ; , , ] : continued fraction (the brackets are optional)
  • { ; , , } : Egyptian fraction

Greek numerals

  • Î‘ Î’ Î“ Î” Î• Ïš Î– Î— Î˜ : 1â€¦9
  • Î™ Îš Î› Îœ Î Î ÎŸ Î  Ï : 10â€¦90
  • Î¡ Î£ Î¤ Î¥ Î¦ Î§ Î¨ Î© Ï  : 100â€¦900
  • Íµ : multiplies following letter by 1000
  • . : multiplies preceding part by 10000 (a myriad)
  • â—‹ : zero

Roman numerals

  • I V X L C D M or â†€ : 1â€¦1000
  • â† â†‚ â†‡ â†ˆ or I)) ((I)) I))) (((I))) : 5000, 10 000, 50 000, 100 000
  • | or ! : multiplies by 100 000
  • . : S (and up to 5 dots): uncia = twelfth, sextans = sixth, semis = half
  • N : nulla/nihil = zero

Base tokens

â€¦ can be customized in the settings. Put them in front of a number. The default values are:

  • @ : standard binary (2)
  • %23 : standard octal (8)
  • $ (or â‚¬, Â£, Â¥): standard decimal (10)
  • % : standard dozenal (12)
  • & : standard hexadecimal (16)

Unicode characters

  • \"ğŸ’ƒ : Dancer

Version 1.9.0

Calculations are now done in the background to improve the appâ€™s responsiveness when calculating very long representations.

Base phi: Qonvert can calculate Egyptian fractions for phinary with the greedy and the phinary remainder methods. And when an â€œirrationalâ€ error turns up, you can tap â›¶ to show the offending input in standardized form in all different formats.

You can change base and numeral system directly on the All formats and Musical intervals screens.

And as always: tweaks and fixes.

Version 1.8.0 â€“ 3 Apr 2023

Bases up to Â±280 are supported, and balanced bases up to Â±259, using increasingly exotic digits. Phinary balanced is now also supported, for which you can use Z = âˆ’1 as an input digit.

The settings have been slightly rearranged. They contain a new section â€œKeyboardâ€ with an option â€œSpace key composes digitâ€; if itâ€™s switched on, you can compose a digit by typing its decimal value and then tapping Space (â£). In the â€œAppearanceâ€ section, you can choose between serif, sans-serif, and monospace fonts for input and output areas and for the keyboard.

New musical intervals: Pythagorean wolf fourth and fifth as examples of dissonant intervals, as well as septimal (7-limit) tuning. Interval sizes are also shown in cents.

The help text now has a chapter on complex bases.

Minor improvements and a bugfix: A crash on inputting numbers with high digits in large negative bases has been fixed.

Version 1.7.1 â€“ 7 Jan 2023

There are three additional keyboard layouts: with the digits starting on the left edge, for tablets (with 12 columns even in portrait mode), and a combination of the two. You can choose in the settings, in the â€œAppearanceâ€ section. The keyboard pop-ups now show the digitsâ€™ values.

The list screens (All formats, History, Musical intervals) have got a new display option, â€œdissectâ€, which shows digits with values outside the range 0â€¦9 as decimal numbers (such as Z5Å¢â‚†â‚€ as 35 5 59â‚†â‚€).

A crash on input of a character with a Unicode code point > FFFFâ‚â‚† has been fixed, as well as some minor issues.

Version 1.7.0 â€“ 25 Dec 2022

Phinary, the golden ratio base, is now supported. On the sliders, it is located on the leftmost tick. Also, bases up to Â±100 are supported.

Qonvert can now count digits â€“ as well as denominators of continued and Egyptian fractions â€“ of the list screensâ€™ individual entries. Tap the â‹® on the right edge to bring up the new menu items.

â€œÂ½â€ on Qonvertâ€™s keyboard (long-tap the radix point) brings up a pop-up with fraction characters.

Setting a negative base italicises the base buttons for added clarity.

Speed has been improved (again), especially for repeating digits and for large bases. And needless to say: bugfixes.

Version 1.6.0 â€“ 5 Nov 2022

Bases up to 70 are now supported, including negative ones. On the settings screen, you can activate new base buttons for sexagesimal (base 60).

The base tokens (@ %23 $ % &) can be customized in the settings to represent any valid combination of base and numeral system.

Degrees, minutes and seconds: non-integer seconds are also shown as fractions.

I removed support for complement notation in bijective systems; I have to admit that this never made any sense.

Many fixes and improvements â€“ for example, you can now delete history entries by swiping them away.

Version 1.5.0 â€“ 9 Oct 2022

Negative bases are now supported. Long-tap one of the base buttons to bring up a dialog for choosing any base, including negative ones. There are also buttons to switch between positive and negative bases; you can show or hide them in the settings under â€œShow base buttonsâ€.

Degrees, minutes and seconds (DMS, such as 1Â° 45\' 10\") are supported.

âš ï¸ The repetition sign has been changed to a dot above Ë™ (or you can use a colon :) to make way for the minutes sign. The keyboard layout has been adapted slightly. Sorry for the inconvenience!

Unicode character names are shown on the all formats screen in â€œprettyâ€ format (for Android version 4.4 KitKat and higher).

Settings: Auto-scrolling of the output area when the output doesnâ€™t fit can now be switched off. Text size now also affects the DMS- and complement-switches and the â€œin: baseâ€ and â€œout: baseâ€ texts. And the height of the switches area can be increased.

Version 1.4.1 â€“ 17 Jul 2022

Improvements and bugfixes to the waveform display of musical intervals: the phase shift can now be changed by swiping.

Version 1.4.0 â€“ 16 May 2022

Greek (Milesian) numerals are now fully supported.

Playing a musical interval now also shows a waveform of this interval. (These are examples; for different phase shifts waveforms of the same interval look different.)

On the list screens you can now select a whole range of entries at once by long-tapping the one at the start of the range and then long-tapping the one at the end.

â€¦ and bugfixes, as usual.

Version 1.3.0 â€“ 2 Apr 2022

Qonvert has a new keyboard! (for Android version 5 Lollipop and higher) â€“ It adapts to the current input system and to your phoneâ€™s orientation. To access the second character on a key, long-tap it. You can vanish the keyboard by tapping â—€ on the navigation bar or by swiping down; tap the input line for it to re-emerge.
If you want the standard Android keyboard back, you can choose it in the settings.

Tap â™« in the title bar to play a musical interval with the given frequency ratio. As of this version, the name of the interval, or the nearest named interval, is displayed. The menu item â€œMusical intervalsâ€ lists all known interval names and their values.

The list screens now have a third option for displaying, copying and sharing numbers: â€œcompatibleâ€, which aims at maximum compatibility with other mathematics apps (at least for the less obscure number bases and systems).

Natural numbers are now also shown as Greek numerals. If the output area is too cluttered for your taste, you can hide them in the settings (or you could hide the Roman numerals, or the Unicode symbols).

Next to Unicode symbols in the history and on the all formats screen thereâ€™s a new button opening a web link about that symbol (on fileformat.info).

Version 1.2.0 â€“ 18 Feb 2022

There is a new screen called All formats which opens when you tap â›¶. It lets you copy and share your calculation results. The appearance of the history is new, providing the same functionality as the all formats screen.

Output of Egyptian fractions is supported now. You can choose a calculation method for the main screen in the settings; the results of the other methods are available on the all formats screen.

Support for German was added. Also, speed has been improved significantly.

Version 1.1.0 â€“ 26 Jan 2021

The switches for balanced numeral systems have been replaced with dropdown menus which let you choose between standard, balanced, bijective and Roman numerals. You can still toggle between standard and balanced systems with a long tap. See the Help page for how these new systems work.

On the settings screen, you can activate new base buttons for hexavigesimal (base 26).

Input of Egyptian fractions is supported: {2;3,4 is interpreted as 2 + 1/3 + 1/4 = 2_7/12.

You can now use fraction characters such as Â¾ and use them in numbers: 2Â¾.

The main menu has a new entry â€œCheat sheetâ€ with an overview over the control gestures on the main screen, as well as the input syntax. (Now you can swipe right to get there.)

Many fixes and improvements â€“ for example, calculating digits of long repeating parts is faster now.

Version 1.0.0 â€“ 20 Dec 2020

Initial release with standard and balanced numeral systems as well as Roman output for positive integers and Unicode characters, and playing musical intervals (by tapping â™«).

Thank you for using Qonvert!

This is a toy and maybe an educational tool, and itâ€™s free. It was written by me, Anypodetos. If you have any suggestions or questions, or you want to report a bug, or you just want to tell me whether you like this app, please contact me.
